Calculate age-specific mortality rates

mortalityRates.Rd

Calculate age-specific mortality rates from number of deaths and population by single years of age or age groups.

Usage

mortalityRates(
  population,
  deaths,
  start = 0:(n - 1),
  end = start,
  day = 182,
  leapyear = FALSE,
  a0 = 0.7,
  a1 = 0.6
)

Arguments

population

number of individuals in the age interval

deaths

number of deaths in the age interval during the calendar year

start

the age in years at the start of each age interval; if missing, then the default is single years from 0 to n - 1, where n is the number of intervals

end

the age in years at the end of each interval; the default is start, which produces single-year intervals; if the last interval is open-ended then end[n] can be Inf

day

day of the year on which population was measured; may be a number, defaulting to 182 (July 1 in a non-leap-year), or any value that can be interpreted by the yday() function in the lubridate package

leapyear

TRUE if day occurs in a leap-year (default is FALSE)

a0

proportion of deaths that take place during the first half of the first year of life, default 0.7; used only if the first age interval is the single year age 0

a1

proportion of deaths that take place during the first half of the second year of life, default 0.6; used only if the second age interval is the single year from age 1

Value

a data frame with, for single-year data, columns for age and the one-year mortality.rate, or, for age-grouped data, columns for the start and end in years of each age group, and the one-year mortality.rate.

Details

Calculates the single-year mortality rate at each age or in each age group. First, population size on January 1 is approximated by adding the interpolated number of deaths between January 1 and the date at which population is measured, assuming that deaths are evenly spread throughout the year (with the exception of the first and second single years of life, where a0 and a1 proportion of deaths, respectively, are assumed to occur during the first half of each of these years of life).

See also

lifetable, yday

Author

John Fox jfox@mcmaster.ca

Examples

(mortality2023 <- with(CanadaDeaths2023,  
                       mortalityRates(population.female, deaths.female,
                             start=start, end=end, day="2023-07-02")))
#>    start end mortality.rate
#> 1      0   4   0.0009275671
#> 2      5   9   0.0000947616
#> 3     10  14   0.0001137818
#> 4     15  19   0.0002627952
#> 5     20  24   0.0004210210
#> 6     25  29   0.0005616452
#> 7     30  34   0.0007019620
#> 8     35  39   0.0008942950
#> 9     40  44   0.0010820402
#> 10    45  49   0.0015514477
#> 11    50  54   0.0022832834
#> 12    55  59   0.0035546127
#> 13    60  64   0.0055723295
#> 14    65  69   0.0087431570
#> 15    70  74   0.0137915118
#> 16    75  79   0.0234766454
#> 17    80  84   0.0409016028
#> 18    85  89   0.0749005414
#> 19    90  94   0.1360996611
#> 20    95  99   0.2285092327
#> 21   100 Inf   0.3635425985
with(mortality2023, lifetable(mortality2023$mortality.rate,
                              start=start, end=end))
#>                 l[x]  d[x]    p[x]    q[x]   L[x]    T[x]      e[x]
